subtopics.name: Atoms & Elements
subtopics.theory:
An atom consists of a nucleus (protons and neutrons) surrounded by electrons. The atomic number ($Z$) is the number of protons; the mass number ($A$) is protons plus neutrons.

Electrons are arranged in energy levels (shells). The electron configuration determines an element's chemical properties. The periodic table organizes elements by atomic number and groups them by similar properties.

Isotopes are atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons.

examples.question: Write the electron configuration of Carbon ($Z = 6$).

subtopics.name: Types of Bonds
subtopics.theory:
Chemical bonds form when atoms share or transfer electrons to achieve stable electron configurations.

Ionic bonds: electrons are transferred from metal to non-metal, creating ions held together by electrostatic attraction. Example: NaCl.

Covalent bonds: electrons are shared between non-metal atoms. Can be single, double, or triple bonds. Example: $H_2O$.

Metallic bonds: electrons are delocalized among metal atoms, creating a 'sea of electrons' that allows conductivity.

examples.question: What type of bond forms between Na and Cl?

subtopics.name: The Mole Concept
subtopics.theory:
The mole is the SI unit for amount of substance. One mole contains $6.022 \times 10^{23}$ particles (Avogadro's number).

Molar mass is the mass of one mole of a substance (in g/mol), numerically equal to the atomic/molecular mass. For example, water ($H_2O$) has molar mass $18.02$ g/mol.

Conversions: moles $= \frac{\text{mass}}{\text{molar mass}}$, and number of particles $= \text{moles} \times 6.022 \times 10^{23}$.

examples.question: How many moles are in $36$ g of water ($H_2O$)?

subtopics.name: pH and Acid-Base Reactions
subtopics.theory:
Acids donate protons ($H^+$) and bases accept protons (Br√∏nsted-Lowry definition). The pH scale measures acidity: $\text{pH} = -\log[H^+]$.

pH < 7 is acidic, pH = 7 is neutral, pH > 7 is basic. Strong acids/bases fully dissociate in water; weak acids/bases partially dissociate.

Neutralization: acid + base ‚Üí salt + water. Example: $HCl + NaOH \rightarrow NaCl + H_2O$.

examples.question: What is the pH of a solution with $[H^+] = 10^{-4}$ M?

subtopics.name: Hydrocarbons
subtopics.theory:
Organic chemistry studies carbon-based compounds. Hydrocarbons contain only carbon and hydrogen.

Alkanes ($C_nH_{2n+2}$): single bonds only, saturated. Examples: methane ($CH_4$), ethane ($C_2H_6$).
Alkenes ($C_nH_{2n}$): contain at least one C=C double bond, unsaturated.
Alkynes ($C_nH_{2n-2}$): contain at least one C‚â°C triple bond.
